content.body: jjaschke (out until Dec 1), smaug, if you're around at TPAC we can perhaps do some navigation API whiteboarding to resolve some of the pending messy issues. I understand farre won't be there unfortunately. Anyone else who's around is welcome of course (e.g. Dominic Farolino)
content.formatted_body: jjaschke (out until Dec 1), smaug, if you're around at TPAC we can perhaps do some navigation API whiteboarding to resolve some of the pending messy issues. I understand farre won't be there unfortunately. Anyone else who's around is welcome of course (e.g. Dominic Farolino)

content.body: I'll be there

I don't think wait-for-all is that messy. The spec is mostly good in that case, and API is part of interop, so "encouraging browsers to precisely match the web standards " ðŸ˜‰  But yeah, that issue, and perhaps others too should be discussed.
And we should also discuss about that "encouraging browsers to precisely match the web standards " part.
It's messy when there is a divergence between WPTs and spec which in some cases begs the question of which one is correct.
anyway, I saw that the process/meta question is already on the agenda requests but what I want is to spend a bit of time on the specifics and make sure we make the right decisions for users/web-devs.
Sure.
I must admit that I'm surprised by the amount of divergence

I wasn't involved when it was spec'ed/implemented but I remember that there was a huge hanging PR with a lot of details for quite a while, and the prototype was progressing alongside the spec. So it caught me by surprise as well but also it's not totally unexpected given the complexity of this API
Or Session History and Navigation in genereal
* Or Session History and Navigation in general

m.new_content.body: Or Session History and Navigation in general

content.body: Yea exactly. I am curious as to whether this is an outlier or there are other recent examples of this kind of divergence/complexity. Answering this can help the meta conversation.

Trusted types was perhaps a bit similar, though there through some great collaboration specs and implementations got into a lot better shape. But it did mean filing spec issues and fixing them when the spec wasn't implementable and also writing tests following the spec, not the first implementation.
Yea I see that TrustedTypes landed in 2019, and there were some recent spec-alignment changes
"some" ðŸ™‚ And lots of new tests
(I can't thank FrÃ©dÃ©ric enough for writing tons of tests)
content.formatted_body: (I can't thank FrÃ©dÃ©ric enough for writing tons of tests)

content.body: annevk zcorpan Jake Archibald: Noam Rosenthal and I are working on `streamHTMLUnsafe()` and would like to use the stages process, and would like to move https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2142 to stage 1. (https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/11669 is also very relevant, but we don't need two issues in the stages process I think.)
